nexttext:
where $\dot{A}(t)$  and $\dot{A}_1(t)$ are the complex envelopes providing high range resolution; $T$, $T_1$ are the repetition periods of the signal and  the strobe; $T_1=T+\Delta T$;  $\Delta T=2TV_r/c$  is  the sampling increment ($\Delta T \ll T,T_1$).

The value of stroboscopic sample of a signal in the $k$-th sampling period can be presented as
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\dot{x}(t)=\sum_{k=0}^{N}{A(t-kT)e^{j[\omega_{0}t+\theta(t)]}},\qquad\dot{a}(t%
)=\sum_{k=0}^{N}{A_{1}(t-kT_{1})e^{j\omega_{1}t}}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>x</mi><mo>˙</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mi>N</mi></munderover><mrow><mi>A</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>θ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="22.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>a</mi><mo>˙</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mi>N</mi></munderover><mrow><msub><mi>A</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: Let us assume $\theta(t)$  be a stationary random zero-mean process with correlation window  $\tau_\theta$ exceeding the duration of strobe signals. Let us suppose also that slow phase displacements are tracked by stabilizing system, wherefore one can neglect the correlation of adjacent samples $\{\theta_k\}$  and set $\langle\theta_i\theta_k\rangle=\sigma^2_\theta\delta_{ik}$ . This allows for presentation of the sample $\dot{y}_k$  in the form

where $\dot{A}(t)$  and $\dot{A}_1(t)$ are the complex envelopes providing high range resolution; $T$, $T_1$ are the repetition periods of the signal and  the strobe; $T_1=T+\Delta T$;  $\Delta T=2TV_r/c$  is  the sampling increment ($\Delta T \ll T,T_1$).

The value of stroboscopic sample of a signal in the $k$-th sampling period can be presented as
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\dot{y}_{k}=\frac{1}{2T}\int_{kT}^{(k+1)T}A(t-kT)A_{1}(t-kT_{1})e^{j[\Omega t+%
\theta(t)]}dt." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>y</mi><mo>˙</mo></mover><mi>k</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>A</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>A</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>θ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where $\theta_k=\theta(kT_1)$  is the sample of the random process $\theta(t)$  and $\dot{y}_{k0}$  stands for the stroboscopic sample \eqref{yk} when there is no phase instability in the signal processing system. To ensure the mode of âultra-high-resolutionâ of radar signatures of asteroids \cite{ZakhKovpatent14} one has to use nanosecond signals with pulse ratio of order $10^3-10^6$, thus, the aforementioned approximations are perfectly acceptable.

The average value (mathematical expectation) of samples \eqref{yk} obtained by averaging over phase $\theta_k$  can be expressed as
prevtext: Let us assume $\theta(t)$  be a stationary random zero-mean process with correlation window  $\tau_\theta$ exceeding the duration of strobe signals. Let us suppose also that slow phase displacements are tracked by stabilizing system, wherefore one can neglect the correlation of adjacent samples $\{\theta_k\}$  and set $\langle\theta_i\theta_k\rangle=\sigma^2_\theta\delta_{ik}$ . This allows for presentation of the sample $\dot{y}_k$  in the form
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\dot{y}_{k}\approx\frac{e^{j[\Omega kT_{1}+\theta_{k}]}}{2T}\int_{0}^{T}A(t^{%
\prime})A_{1}(t^{\prime}-k\Delta T)dt=\dot{y}_{k0}e^{j\theta_{k}}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>y</mi><mo>˙</mo></mover><mi>k</mi></msub><mo>≈</mo><mrow><mfrac><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>θ</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></msup><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mn>0</mn><mi>T</mi></msubsup><mrow><mi>A</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>t</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>A</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msup><mi>t</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>y</mi><mo>˙</mo></mover><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>θ</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where $\beta=\langle \exp[j\theta_k] \rangle = \chi_{\theta}(1)$; $\chi_{\theta}(\nu)$  is the characteristic function of the distribution law of phase fluctuations $W(\theta_k)$. For the normal process with zero mean $W(\theta_k)=N(0,\sigma^2_{\theta})$ this value is equal to  $\beta= \exp[-0.5 \sigma^2_{\theta}] < 1$.

Variance  of samples $\dot{y}_k$  amounts to $D\dot{y}_k = \langle |\dot{y}_k-M\dot{y}_k|^2\rangle = |\dot{y}_{k0}|^2(1-\beta^2)$  under the assumptions made. The ratio of variance to squared  mean value is
